title: Horse race that stops a one pub town
text:
Wallabadah Cup: The horse race that stops a one pub town Peter Lorimer, The Daily Telegraph January 2, 2017 12:51pm 
IT’S the horse race that has stopped a small country town on New Year’s Day every year since 1852. 
And the running of the 165th Wallabadah Cup meeting on Sunday was no exception as more than 2000 revellers converged on the iconic bush track nestled in the foothills of the Great Dividing Range south of Tamworth. 
With Akubra Hats and RM Williams boots the preferred dress code, the one pub town literally shuts down to welcome the New Year. media_camera Punters gather ahead of the race. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera Dot Ross, of Halls Creek watches race four. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera The race caller perched atop a platform with his binoculars. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera And they’re off! The first race on the card at Wallabadah. Picture: Peter Lorimer. 
Many of the partygoers only get as far as the car park while seasoned punters try their best to pick a winner on the five race card, featuring the Wallabadah Cup. 
The track is unique, crafted on the side of a plains grass hill with barbed wire fencing skirting the outer perimeter on the back section of the course. 
The old bush bar gets a workout from the time the gates open, while the race caller gives his description perched on a stand on top of the weatherboard office. media_camera Bush hoop Terry Green steers Classic Attitude to back-to-back Wallabadah victories. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera The track is unique, crafted on the side of a plains grass hill with barbed wire fencing. Picture: Peter Lorimer. 
He often loses the horses as they pass behind several big gumtrees down the back straight. 
Wallabadah once had three pubs during the gold rush and one of the publicans, Jonathon Cock, decided to organise a horse race to settle a bet. media_camera The bush bar is always a popular spot to beat the heat in Wallabadah. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera Patsy Jehner, of Manilla, tries to sort out a winner. Picture: Peter Lorimer. media_camera Al Strachan, Will Evans, Maeve Lawson, Nellie Evans, and Eloise Rocca get into the spirit of things at the 165th Wallabadah Cup. Picture: Peter Lorimer. 
In 1852 a course was pegged out around the town and the tradition was born. 
The racetrack was relocated in 1897, adjacent to the New England Highway and two years later the committee purchased a starting machine. 
Sunday’s Cup was taken out by Classic Attitude ($3.25) for the second year in a row with country hoop TJ Green standing proud in the irons as he crossed the finish line. 
President Bill Kelly is the driving force behind keeping the meeting alive. 
“It’s traditional bush racing at its best and a small band of dedicated volunteers work very hard to keep the dream alive every year,” he said.
